article.headline: North Carolina State 92, Wofford 88
article.story: RALEIGH, N.C. (AP) -- Sidney Lowe couldn't enjoy his debut as North Carolina State's coach until the horn finally sounded. Engin Atsur scored 24 points and hit the go-ahead layup in the final minute Friday night to help the Wolfpack hold off Wofford 92-88, giving Lowe a successful start at the helm of the program he helped lead to a national championship as a player. Ben McCauley scored 17 of his 26 points in the second half for the Wolfpack, which rallied from a nine-point halftime deficit and held on in a wild final few minutes for its 13th straight season-opening win. It was enough to have Lowe -- the point guard on the "Cardiac Pack" team that stunned Houston on a last-second dunk to win the 1983 NCAA title -- joking afterward, "It was no fun out there." "You take a win any way you can get it," he said. On this night, that meant weathering 16 3-point baskets from the Terriers (0-1) and holding on in a back-and-forth final six minutes that featured seven lead changes. It was quite a test for Lowe, who took over for Herb Sendek when Sendek left for Arizona State after 10 seasons here. "I don't know when it's going to hit me," said Lowe, who has spent the past 15 seasons coaching in the NBA. "It's just good we won the ball game. We're very fortunate we came out with that one. ... I'm happy for the guys -- the hard work and effort they put to come back -- that it turned out good for them." Fittingly, a senior made the play to put N.C. State ahead for good. With Wofford leading by one, Atsur split two defenders on the left side then floated by Tyler Whatley in the paint for the score and an 89-88 lead with 42 seconds left. The Wolfpack then got two key stops, starting when Courtney Fells blocked a 3-point attempt by Shane Nicholas with 15.9 seconds left. After Brandon Costner hit a free throw to make it 90-88 with 15.9 seconds to play, Eric Marshall missed a 3 and Atsur grabbed the rebound, then drew the foul and hit two free throws with 2.9 seconds left to seal it. It was a disappointing loss for the Terriers, who have nine returning lettermen from a team that went 11-18 last season. Marshall and Drew Gibson each scored 18 points to lead Wofford, which led 76-71 on Marshall's jumper with 7:42 left before the Wolfpack made the decisive push. "Unacceptable," Wofford coach Mike Young said. "We did some great things, but let's not think that making a lot of shots -- and that's what we did -- let's not let that disguise a poor effort on the defensive end. We gave them too many easy baskets." Still, it's clear that Lowe -- who is touting the tradition of the Wolfpack and building a program worthy of that history -- has plenty of work ahead with a team picked to finish last in the Atlantic Coast Conference. Much of the preseason talk focused on the Wolfpack's offense evolving from Sendek's Princeton-style system to Lowe's up-tempo scheme. But, on Friday at least, the Wolfpack's bigger concern came at the other end of the floor. Wofford shot 66 percent in the first half, including 11-for-19 from 3-point range, to take a 54-45 lead at the break on Nicholas' 3 just before the horn. The scores came from just about everywhere, sparked primarily by kick outs off penetration past Wolfpack defenders. It wasn't until N.C. State tightened up on the perimeter that the Wolfpack closed the gap. "We had high expectations from our defense," Atsur said. "They shot the ball really well. ... But in the second half, Coach Lowe did a great job of adjusting to their offense. We stayed at home with their shooters." The Wolfpack had a much easier time on offense. N.C. State shot 55 percent, with Atsur going 9-for-14 from the floor and hitting four 3s. McCauley, a 6-foot-9 sophomore, also provided a boost with his strong second half that provided an inside scoring threat to complement Atsur and Gavin Grant (15 points) on the perimeter. "I think we came out a little bit slow in the first half," said McCauley, who shot 10-for-13 from the floor. "We weren't playing too good defensively. But in the second half, we picked it up and we did what we're supposed to do and what we're going to do the rest of the season."

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
